Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Carbon spheres (CSs) and low content nitrogen (2.5 and 3.5 at%) doped carbon spheres (NCSs) were synthesized by a pyrolysis process at 900 °C using
C 2
H 2
$\mathrm{C}_{2}\mathrm{H}_{2}$ and CH3CN. The electronic structure and chemical bonding of CSs and NCSs were studied using Raman spectroscopy, valence-band photoemission spectroscopy (VBPES) and X-ray absorption near-edge structure spectroscopy (XANES). XANES spectroscopy showed the effect of carbon and nitrogen bonds and graphitic as well as pyridinic structures on the NCS structure. For the spheres VBPES showed the effect of nitrogen on the spectral shape of the density of states and confirmed the role played by the
π
$\pi$ bonds in controlling the electronic and structural properties of the NCSs. VBPES also showed that both
π
$\pi$ and
σ
$\sigma$ bands shift towards higher binding energies after N-doping which is consistent with the XANES data. The consistency of the spherical geometry, chemical purity, suitable electronic/bonding structure and the availability of macroscopic quantities of the N–CSs makes these spheres promising new materials for different applications.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Over the last few decades, different forms of carbon materials with tunable sizes and shapes have been made to provide electronic grade material for the development of micro-/nano-devices in many related research fields. Among the carbon materials synthesized, carbon spheres (CSs) have attracted considerable attention due to their excellent properties and potential applications in the fields of gas storage [1], sensing [2], catalyst supports [3], and lithium-ion batteries [4]. Doping of carbon (e.g. with N) generates carbons with enhanced properties that can act as a metal-free electrode showing excellent electro-catalytic activity [5], longer-term operation stability, insensitivity to CO poisoning and tolerance to crossover effects in the oxygen reduction reaction in alkaline fuel cells [6]. Nitrogen-doped carbon materials can be used in the fabrication of devices such as capacitors [6], in spintronics [7], and in energy conversion and storage devices [8].

In this present study we have incorporated N into CSs using a pyrolysis process at 900 °C. The electronic and atomic/bonding properties [2, 6–8] of these NCSs were studied using Raman spectroscopy, valence-band photoemission spectroscopy (VBPES) and X-ray absorption near-edge structure spectroscopy (XANES) [9, 10]. The NCSs produced have a low doping content (2.5 and 3.5 at%) and the new carbons could be very useful in different electronic applications [2–4].

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para:
XANES and VBPES measurements were carried out on various beamlines at the National Synchrotron Radiation Research Center, Hsinchu, Taiwan. The XANES data were measured using a sample drain current in total electron yield mode and VB-PES spectra were obtained at base pressure of
∼ 5 ×
10
− 10
${\sim}5 \times 10^{-10}$ Torr using an excitation energy of ∼50 eV. A Jobin Yvon T64000 Raman spectrometer equipped with an Ar ion laser (514.5 nm) was used to examine the structure of the films. The laser power on the sample was 5 mW and the spectra were recorded over a 20-s period having LASER beam spot size of ∼1 μm. The synthesis of CSs and N–CSs was carried out using a pyrolysis process as described elsewhere [11]. In particular, the CS and NCS materials were produced in a CVD process. Argon and
C 2
H 2
$\mathrm{C}_{2}\mathrm{H}_{2}$ were bubbled through toluene (or acetonitrile) and the gas mixture was passed through a quartz tube heated to 900 °C for 1 h. The quartz reactor was set up in two different geometries: a horizontal and a vertical configuration. In the vertical mode the carbon spheres produced (doped and undoped) only remain at a high temperature for seconds. The carbons produced in the horizontal reactor were subjected to the oven reaction temperature for the full reaction time. The degree of graphitization of the carbon was thus different for the carbons produced by the two different procedures. At the end of the reaction the reactant gas flow was discontinued and pure argon was flowed through the quartz reactor while the product cooled to room temperature. The product collected was purified by Soxhlet extraction (toluene); it contained no catalyst impurities as typically found in the equivalent carbon nanotube materials.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The surface morphology of the CSs was studied using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images are shown in Figs. 1(a)–1(c) for pure CSs and NCSs produced in a vertical reactor (3.5 N at%) and NCSs produced in a horizontal reactor (2.5 N at%). The CSs possess a characteristic sphere-shaped morphology and their sizes vary with the reaction procedure used (Figs. 1(a)–1(c)). The formation of the densely packed spherical structure is due to a minimization of the interfacial/surface energies between the spheres. The NCSs have a diameter distribution between 55 and 900 nm which depends upon the orientation of the reactor (either horizontal or vertical) that was used during the synthesis process. The NCSs (and CSs) produced in a vertical reactor produced spheres with sizes that varied from 55 to 475 nm (average size = 125 nm; the NCSs had a larger average diameter). The size increased to 100–900 nm (average size = 450 nm) when the tube was placed in the horizontal furnace. We have found that 3.5 at% N is incorporated when using the tube in a vertical direction, whereas 2.5 at% N is incorporated when using the tube in a horizontal direction. The lower value of the N content in the NCSs made in the horizontal reactor could relate to the removal of N with time at the high reaction temperature. Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para:
CSs and N–CSs (2.5–3.5 N at%) were synthesized by a CVD process. XANES was used to interpret the electronic and bonding structures from the C and N
K
$K$ -edges of the CSs and NCSs. The contribution from C–N bonds and nitrogen in the NCSs has been separated from the contribution of the graphite structure. This structure is found to be similar to pyridine. VBPES data showed the effect of nitrogen on the spectral shape of the DOS and, in particular, the sensitivity of the
p – π
$p\mbox{--}\pi$ DOS to the presence of nitrogen. It confirms the role played by the
π
$\pi$ bonds in controlling the electronic structure of N–CSs. The increase of intensity of the
p – π
$p\mbox{--}\pi$ transition after functionalization with nitrogen indicates an increase in the defect density and size of the graphitic islands formed by the clustering of
π
$\pi$ states in aromatic rings. VBPES studies showed that the valence band was shifted to lower binding energy due to the nitrogen doping which caused Fermi level shifts to the conduction band edge. The enhancement of electron density near the top of the valence band and the rise of the valence band peak are related to the N substitution in the carbon network. The CSs and N–CSs are not free from atmospheric contaminants. Oxygen signals were observed in the X-ray photoemission analysis as well as from the VBPES data. The absorption of oxygen on CSs and N–CSs suggests that these materials could be used in absorber devices. With improved fabrication techniques, absorber devices based on CSs/N–CSs can offer a potential solution for passive optical transmission systems and other optoelectronic applications.
